user_prompt: From 'If the essay is well-written, then the student will get an A', can we infer 'If the essay is well-written and turned in late, then the student will get an A'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
I need to evaluate whether we can infer "If the essay is well-written and turned in late, then the student will get an A" from "If the essay is well-written, then the student will get an A."

From a purely formal logical perspective, this would be an instance of monotonicity (or strengthening the antecedent): if P → Q, then (P ∧ R) → Q. This is valid in classical logic.

However, I must consider the real-world context and implicit assumptions in this conditional statement.

The original statement "If the essay is well-written, then the student will get an A" operates under normal academic conditions. There are implicit background assumptions, including:
- The essay is submitted on time
- Academic policies are followed
- No violations of academic integrity occur

When we add "turned in late" to the antecedent, we're introducing a condition that likely contradicts these implicit normal circumstances. In most academic contexts:
- Late submissions typically result in grade penalties
- Getting an A usually requires meeting all requirements, including deadlines
- The grading policy implicitly assumes timely submission

The addition of "turned in late" doesn't just add neutral information—it introduces a condition that would typically prevent getting an A, regardless of the essay's quality. This violates the implicit "all else being equal" or "under normal conditions" clause that accompanies the original conditional.

Therefore, while the inference would be valid in pure formal logic, it fails when we consider the real-world meaning and implicit conditions of the statement.

Answer: no
